newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia cuts foreigner T-bill yield to 11.0 pct.
newsitem.headline: Russia cuts foreigner T-bill yield to 11.0 pct.

text.p: The Central Bank said on Wednesday it was cutting the guaranteed dollar yield to non-residents investing in Russian Treasury bills to 11.0 percent as of June 2 from 12.5 percent currently.

The move, part of a gradual liberalisation of the government securities market, will be accompanied by a cut in the proportion of foreign exchange forward deals which banks handling non-resident accounts must offset with the Central Bank, it said in a statement. From June 2 banks will only have to offset 20 percent of non-residents' cash rouble purchases to buy T-bills with the Central Bank instead of 40 percent, said the statement from the head of the bank's currency division.
The proportion of non-residents' forward rouble sales to repatriate profits from T-bills which must be offset falls to 40 percent from 50 percent.
These compensatory deals allow the Central Bank to influence the rates which commercial banks offer non-residents, and hence the overall return which non-residents can obtain.
The Central Bank has said it would gradually reduce and virtually eliminate these restrictions by the beginning of next year to allow non-residents equal access to the market.
At the same time, the guaranteed minimum yield will be abandoned. Foreigners can already make substantially higher profits through active trading of T-bills.
The current rouble yield for T-bills averages about 27 percent.
